comments.text:
+derpeth, I say! It has to do with quantum mechanics. It seems quite likely 
there is a minimum amount of energy you can have, which is called a quanta 
of energy, and it can't be divided. This is the first of Plank's units (h).

It also seems quite likely there is a maximum speed you can reach, which is 
the speed of light in vacuum (c). Speed is associated with the medium 
through which the object travels, and so the speed of light is related to 
the essential fabric of spacetime.

You also have the gravitational constant (G), which is related to who knows 
what.

Well, Plank's length comes from combining these natural and essential 
parameters, constrained by the nature of spacetime and the minimum energy 
you can have, and thus you get the minimum amount of space you can divide 
into.

L = (Gxh/c^3)^0.5

Which about 10^-33 m if I recall correctly.

All this is pure speculation (albeit a reasonable one), since that sort of 
distance is waaaaay smaller than what the actual energies we can gather (or 
will be able to in the future) allow us to inspect.
comments.author: Miguel Gómez Donoso

comments.text:
+Ignacio Fernández Herrero
Pardon me, but your explanation is completely wrong.

The 0.9999999(...) explanation was put there to explain that a period of 
nine is just another way to write the natural number coming right 
afterwards, i.e. to explain that 59.999(...) is just 60 written in another 
manner.

Then, your argument can be refuted by just saying and proving that Zeno's 
paradox can just be thrown off the window by the concept of limit or using 
quantic mechanics with the Planck's distance.
For example, Zeno's proposed distance is a continuous sum of  fractions of 
powers of 2:

1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 + 1/32...

this is what, in Calculus, is called a "Convergent series" as it will sum 
up (to infinity) to a precise number.
In this case, that number is the limit for x going to infinite, of that 
sum. Which is precisely 1.
comments.author: Gabriele Maruca

comments.text:
In mathematical notations, a decimal period of 9 (like 0.9999999999999...) 
is another way to write the unit that comes afterwards. For example, 
0.9999999999... is 1, 1.9999999... is 2 and so on.
So the time taken, even if is 59,9999999.... minutes, will be still 1 hour, 
at least in the decimal system we use.

Pi is a totally different story: it's an irrational number, so you can't 
represent it in any shape or for that is a fraction, while the 0.9 period 
can be.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/0.999...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Repeating_decimal
comments.author: Gabriele Maruca

comments.author: Enrico Alessio

comments.text:
Wow, thanks! I'm very intrigued by the golden ratio and will definitely

comments.author: quackpop

comments.text:
It is similar, but it's not the same! The difference is the starting shape. 
In this video, he used a square. The shape related to the fibonacci 
sequence is a rectangle called the golden rectangle. Because of the ratio 
of its width to length, this rectangle has the property that when you cut 
it in half (cutting perpendicular to the wide side), the resulting 
subdivisions are golden rectangles themselves! You can see in the video 
that when he cuts the square in half, the result is not two squares but two 
rectangles.

If you want to learn more, there are a few things you should look up!
Phi (the Golden Ratio) = 1.618...
Golden spiral
Fibonacci Number on wikipedia (scroll down to "Relation to the golden 
ratio")

Have fun!
comments.author: Connor McBryde

comments.text:
This is a very good question. I looked it up right after i saw it in the 
comments. It happens to be that the fibonacci series spiral is exactly the 
same as the spiral with the angle of the golden ratio.

99.9-1%=99.99 ...

top_comment.text:
let x = 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8.....

Multiply the equation by 2

2x = 1 + 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 .....

2x = 1 + (1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8....)

2x = 1 + x  [ because x = (1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8....) ]

2x - x = 1

x = 1 

Hence total distance travelled = 1 miles

:)﻿

top_comment.text:
This still doesn't solve the infinity problem in Zeno's paradox. You are 
just basically twisting the paradox and turning it into a form that can be 
solved easily. Clearly in mathematics there is infinity and different forms 
of infinities but in real life things are different. You can't divide 
objects infinite times, dividing objects smaller than planck lenght require 
so much energy that it would spawn a black hole before you could divide the 
object.

Zeno's paradox leads us to the fundemental structures of our universe and 
even beyond. Using normal physics and math there is 2 conclusions: it takes 
infinite amount of energy to move or moving doesn't require any energy. 
Obviously these two things are not happening in real world. This is where 
quantum physics kick in... When moving lengths smaller than planck length 
you aren't actually affected by common laws of physics and therefore it is 
actually possible to "overcome" infinity﻿

comments.text:
Continuing on... for me, if I am going to choose a semantic interpretation 
I would like it to conform to some real world problem. I really do not care 
about imaginary "concepts". For example one could imagine a rigorous 
semantic proof that red+blue=hot_dog, and that is great, but how is that

comments.author: ThinkTank255

comments.text:
"Math is based on a few axioms from which everything is deduced - most 
often based on circular proofs such as induction."

Induction is not circular if it has a proper base case, as all induction 
should. Also, in many cases the base case is improperly dropped, allowing 
an arbitrary set to defined the base case, hence your confusion. For 
example, it is perfectly valid to choose {1,2 3} as the positive natural 
numbers. The definition explicitly allows the arbitrary choice of the 
positive natural. The set {1,2,3,...} is actually not a properly defined 
set. It is a SELECTION from a collection of sets each of which is finite. 
Yet, this type of mathematical ambiguity is frequently allowed, even 
though, technically incorrect.

"Mathematics depend on the fundamental assumed axioms, which are undefined 
(primitive notions), which makes math circular in nature."

Wrong. Just completely wrong. We MUST get rid of this incorrect 
understanding of mathematics. Contrary to your assertion, axioms ARE ALWAYS 
non-circularly defined syntactically. Semantic interpretations are, 
technically, not even necessary. For any syntactic formalism there exists 
an infinite number of semantic interpretations. Who is to say which one is 
"right"??? That is up to the person reading and interpreting the maths.
comments.author: ThinkTank255

comments.text:
+ThinkTank255 Math is based on a few axioms from which everything is 
deduced - most often based on circular proofs such as induction. 
Mathematics depend on the fundamental assumed axioms, which are undefined 
(primitive notions), which makes math circular in nature.

Now the problem I see here is that you call the definition of infinity 
circular while math itself is based on circular, yet valid, logic.

How about you define what you mean by the definition of infinity being 
circular? Since that is what you are criticizing.
comments.author: Frederik Falk

Zeno knew he was wrong, but the whole point is to force us to think. It

comments.author: Drew Johnson

comments.text:
+paulflute Quoting "What I mean is that conceptual mathematical lines and 
real physical objects have different qualities"
and "simply because actual things have limits.. you can only divide a 
physical thing so far and you reach a limit"
and "So the conceptual distance can be divided infinitely and gives one 
answer whereas the physical thing cannot so gives another"

What I've been saying is that you've got it mixed up. There's no such thing 
as physical and conceptual distance, whether we're talking about an 
imaginative world or the physical one. There's only one distance and that's 
the shortest line from one point to another. Distance is ALWAYS conceptual, 
taking distance as a physical thing is simply not correct. It's like saying 
that speed or angular momentum are physical things, but they are not, they 
are concepts. Distance is a concept at ALL times, in both imagination and 
reality, which is why it can be infinitely divided. If it was a rope 
indicating the distance, then yes, I could not infinitely divide it because 
it is impossible to infinitely divide physical objects. But all along, I've 
been saying that distance is NEVER an object. The points it is concerned 
with may be physical objects, but distance itself is always and at all 
times conceptual.

And yeah, I meant infinitely not equally divided xD My bad.
comments.author: Simon Michalo

comments.text:
+Simon Michalo I don't believe that mathematically lines cannot be applied 
to the real world.. Clearly they can and can be very useful.. What I mean 
is that conceptual mathematical lines and real physical objects have 
different qualities.. The most relevant one being that a measurable 
distance between two real things CANNOT be infinitely divided.. I presume 
that's what you meant (not equally).. simply because actual things have 
limits.. you can only divide a physical thing so far and you reach a 
limit.. either of your ability to divide or of divisible stuff.. So the 
conceptual distance can be divided infinitely and gives one answer whereas 
the physical thing cannot so gives another.. there is no paradox.. they are 
simply different things.. The illusion of a paradox only arises when we use 
the same words for both and forget that they are different and possess 
different qualities..
It would be like trying to solve a math problem where you have an object A 
of size N in an equation with another object A of size Q.. you could never 
do it and would arrive at paradoxical answers .. Nobody would pretend this 
was a great philosophical mystery.. any good mathematician would notice 
that you are simply confusing terms.. Clearly concepts can be and are very 
useful tools.. but they only become 'useful' so to speak when we refer them 
back to reality.. sometimes that may be a convoluted process and may 
journey through other concepts but until they ground in something real they 
have no real bearing on our lives or thought..
comments.author: paulflute

comments.text:
+paulflute Basically, what we disagree on is whether mathematical lines are 
applicable to the real world, to which I say yes and to which you say no, 
My point is, the line of no width that is used in mathematics and mainly 
geometry has been used for more than two millenia and it has served us well 
in both concepts and the real world. When you talk about distance between 
points in the real world, there's no physicality involved. Distance itself 
is a human generated concept. A measurable distance between real things is 
still a concept, it CAN be equally divided. But yeah, this was a nice chat 
:D
comments.author: Simon Michalo

comments.text:
+Simon Michalo yes were labouring the point now and think we'll agree that 
we don't quite agree.. you seem to have  good understanding and overview of 
what i mean anyway so not sure there really is any disagreement but i'd say 
in reply this..
That you are almost trying to avoid the false dichotomy by focusing only on 
one side of it.. My point is that there are two things going on here and 
they are being confused and conflated and you reply by telling me that all 
the math is correct..
I agree all the math is correct, as is all the talk of real things .. it is 
the confusion between the two where the false paradox lies.. Euclid may 
well have defined a line as lacking width in the purely mathematical 
sense.. though he clearly didn't define the word line.. as that's a modern 
english word.. but giving a term a strict scientific definition does not 
then exclude this word from use in general speech.. indeed many if not most 
terms are borrowed /co-opted from the lingua franca in the first place..
So the line you painted on the material is not the same as your 
mathematical concept of width-less line.. That's all I'm saying..
If Zeno had postulated that a hypothetical line drawn between two imaginary 
points on a conceptual hyperbolic matrix could in theory be infinitely 
divisible then nobody would have turned a hair as no paradox is inherent..
He didn't he talked about the distance from here to the park.. real things 
with measurable distances.. So the only paradox is his lack of 
understanding about how to add up things.. and i guess if we are to draw 
anything from this line of thought it's how often we need to refer to 
common sense and the blinking obvious in order to correct and inform the 
abstract and conceptual.. beed nice chating though..    ;9)
comments.author: paulflute

comments.text:
+paulflute  What you said about drawing a line "In my world if your piece 
of material is a meter square then the squiggly line could be 1/2 meter 
wide and go up and back so be 2 m long.. and if it got thinner it gets 
longer.. TO A POINT where it becomes too thin to draw.. Thats fine.. " you 
remain stuck on believing that lines are objects. They are not objects. In 
fact, squares, triangles and other geometrical shapes also aren't objects, 
they are just shapes that define a surface area. 

I'm becoming repetitive, but lines don't have width by definition, they 
never did, ever since the father of Geometry Eucleud defined the "line" 
many years BC. They are not matter, much like with vectors or even 2 
dimensional geometrical shapes. If I cut the shape of a triangle off a 
paper, my triangle is made of matter, so it has width, height(miniscule) 
and length, it's a 3 dimensional object, not a 2 dimensional shape, yet we 
still recognize it as a triangle. It's the same with lines. Drawing a line 
on a paper doesn't mean that lines in general have a width which is 
equivalent to the width of the marking that my ink left on the paper. Lines 
are 1 dimensional geometrical tools that define shapes and the concept of 
length and/or distance. Dismissing this definition as a folly is pretty 
much scrapping not only today's high math but also most of the math that 
man has ever known, if not all of it.

As for infinity now. Infinity is a concept tied to it's core with numbers 
and mathematics. It's the concept that there's no smallest or biggest 
number and I dare you to disprove it. With materials of the real world, I 
can't play with infinity because there are limitations, but with concepts I 
can. And, I'm sorry, but concepts also exist in the real world. For 
example, distance is a concept. If I'm one meter away from you, I can 
reduce that to 1/2 a meter. And then that to 1/4 of a meter. After a bit, I 
reach 1/128 away from you. But I can still divide by two, there's no rule 
that says I can't. So I keep going. 1/256, 1/416, 1/832 and so on and so 
forth. Nothing stops me because I'm not dividing matter by two, I'm 
dividing distance by two, and distance is not material. Zeno claimed that 
since there's always a small distance to cover, I'll never reach you. And 
we found out that the distance between me and you becomes so small that it 
is annuled. Not only that, but we found out that the sum of 1/2 + 1/4 
+...+1/416+1/832+... equals 1 and we defined 1 as the limit of a function.

This "paradox" helped us define limits and work with functions that we 
couldn't use before. Mathematics may get pretty theoretical but they are 
actually bound with the real world and almost never escape from it(except 
imaginary numbers, not quite sure about those). I understand your concern 
completely, but it's only through pondering and pushing our imagination 
that we can discover or invent new things. As a matter of fact, if we use 
basic tools that have been proven to work perfectly, in order to construct 
bigger tools, and then use those tools to construct even bigger ones, 
wouldn't the end product still adhere to the same rules as before? Sure, we 
must be careful to use our tools correctly and watch out for mistakes, but 
that's exactly the point of these "paradoxes". We find flaws in our system 
which we then fix.

By the way, the definition of square root of 2 is "the number which if you 
raise to the power of 2, will produce the number 2". I mentioned it because 
you complained about me using it in a previous comment. Anyway, google 
irrational numbers and you'll see a full explanation on why they all have 
infinite amounts of decimal digits, including square root of 2. Another way 
to see numbers with infinite decimal digits, albeit not irrational ones, is 
by doing divisions like 10/3. We all know the result is 3.3333333333333.... 
and it goes on. It's because of the nature of the division using the 
decimal system that we get this result.

Hope I shone some light over there.

EDIT: I took out the part where I site the function because I made a 
mistake.
comments.author: Simon Michalo

comments.text:
+Simon Michalo Thanks.. I'm glad you agree that this is NOT a paradox.. My 
reason for this however is because it states something that is clearly 
incorrect and I don't feel I need to understand complex math to know that..
Interesting to hear you say that a line in has no width.. Again I 
disagree..  Were you not talking about a line that was painted on a piece 
of material..? Initially at least.. It has width.. then somehow we were 
assuming knowledge about imaginary things.. this it where the slight of 
hand happens.. It's all I'm trying to point out because I think it's 
important.. This is my point.. This slipping between things and non-things 
and trying to carry conclusions across.. In my world if your piece of 
material is a meter square then the squiggly line could be 1/2 meter wide 
and go up and back so be 2 m long.. and if it got thinner it gets longer.. 
TO A POINT where it becomes too thin to draw.. Thats fine.. Your imaginary 
line that has no width has no width.. so it's no a line .. it's a concept.. 
possibly a conceptual line..? but the two things are different.. then 
you're in concept land and you can begin to play with infinities and such 
but you can't then assume that the new concepts that result apply to the 
real world again.. This you have to check and try.. it's called science..So 
yes your imaginary line of infinite length can exist between your two 
imaginary conceptual points.. knock yourself out.. but in the real world 
this is simply no how things actually work.. that's all I'm saying.. there 
is not paradox.. it's simply two entirely different things being spoken 
about with similar or the same words and the speaker confusing them for the 
same thing as a result.. As to whether this is what Zeno was doing or 
intending to do or whether it was simple meant to illustrate some point 
about not assuming things I don't know.. I just think we have to be very 
careful about words and when they shift in meaning however subtly this may 
be they also change in effect.. and so we have to be able to distinguish 
between something that has actual mathematical or scientific interest and 
something which is in fact linguistic like this.. still interesting but in 
a different way.. Does that make sense..?
How have we proved that root 2 is infinite..? (not that i mentioned or 
needed root 2 at any point..) as i said.. if we know the end of this 
sequence it's not infinite.. if we don't then we can't say..  and in the 
real world isn't root 2 simply a line that when used to make a square gives 
you one of area 2 of what ever unit you happen to choose.?  ;9)
comments.author: paulflute

comments.text:
+paulflute First of all, let's clear something up. I don't believe this is 
a paradox, but I also don't think it's just confusion on behalf of a great 
philosopher and mathematician. It helped us find our way to the limit 
theory and define an infinitesimal amount.

Back to the discusion, I brought up "drawing a line" and "lines on 
materials" to make my example more understandable.I quote you "But clearly 
for an infinitely long line to be drawn on a finite surface it would have 
to be infinitely thin. i.e. it's width would have to be (tend towards) 
zero.. i.e. it doesn't exist.." By definition, a line has no width, it only 
has length, it is one dimensional, it covers no surface. Even still, the 
point and the line are both concepts. They are not physical, they are not 
comprised of any material. But existance isn't solely based on having mass. 
Lines and points exist in our perception of the world and are integral in 
how we explain it.

Also, square root of 2 belongs in the same category of numbers as pi and is 
proven to have infinite decimals.

Pythagorean Theorem : If the right triangle is comprised of the three 
points A, B and C,with the hypotenuse being the line BC, the following 
equation is fullfilled (AB)^2 + (AC)^2 = (BC)^2 where (AB) , (AC) and (BC) 
the length of the sides of the triangle. You actually wrote the equation 
yourself, but with words. So, if the length of AB and AC are one 1, as with 
the triangle I introduced before, this becomes 2 = (BC)^2 or (BC) = Square 
Root of 2. Pythagoras may not have lived in the epoch of decimals, but his 
Theorem is always true, so the result I found is valid,

As for your recap, I agree 100% with you that THINGS can not be infinitely 
divided. In the physical world, we hit a barrier when we reach the atom, 
much less the sub-atomic particles. But as I said before, lines are not 
THINGS. They are not physical, they are conceptual. Lines can be infinitely 
divided. A line's length could be 0.000000000000001 or 
0.0000000000000000000000001, or even 10^-30. And when we talk about 
distance between two points, we are talking about a line. Distance CAN be 
inifinitely divided.

Zeno's paradox really isn't a paradox because there was a small but crucial 
flaw in logic that has to do with limits and infinitesimal amounts. But 
excuse me, I don't believe my knowledge allows me to go any further than 
this and make explanations on those theories.
comments.author: Simon Michalo

comments.text:
+Simon Michalo
Thanks.. a quick reply cos life is short but i think you're simply using 
more words that the original false paradox to trick yourself into the same 
semantic contractions without making any further points..  and you assume 
my agreement falsely too..
"So we can agree that any point and any line that I can imagine on a piece 
of material actually exists."  No. we do not agree.. I can imagine an 
infinitely long squiggly line being drawn on a piece of paper as my 
imagination has no physical form and therefore no limits.. But clearly for 
an infinitely long line to be drawn on a finite surface it would have to be 
infinitely thin. i.e. it's width would have to be (tend towards) zero.. 
i.e. it doesn't exist.. which is just my point .. physical things have 
limits: imagination does not.. it's not a paradox.. they're just different 
things..
Your triangle example is equally misled.. Root 2 may or may not have 
infinite decimal places.. we have no way of knowing.. by definition.. As I 
have said.. If we know the limits of an object then it is not infinite. is 
we do not know the limits then we cannot say whether is is infinite or not..
But this is irrelevant as Pythagorus neither used not understood decimal 
places.. they being discovered (in the west) many centuries after his 
death.. His theory states that the sum of the SQUARE of the hypotenuse 
equals the sum of the square of the other two sides.. So it if take a right 
angled triangle and make squares out of the the length of the sides then 
the biggest SQUARE covers the same area as the other two.. that's all.. no 
decimal places or infinities required..
And just incase you are still unsure the word square here refers to a shape 
not a mathematical function..
To recap my point is this.. Zeno's paradox states that the distance between 
to things is infinite because we can subdivide it infinitely.. I say this 
is not a paradox but simply a semantic confusion.. THINGS cannot be 
infinitely divided.. Surly that we can agree on..?
comments.author: paulflute

comments.text:
+paulflute Let's say that you have 2 parallel walls in front you, spaced 1 
meter apart. In my mind, I can imagine a line that connects them and 
contacts both at a 90 degree angle, that line defines thei distance. If I 
take a paintbrush and actually paint that line, does it now exist? Yes, 
since I can see it I guess it does. But what about before I painted it? 
Certainly, the part of the floor that the line covers was already there 
right? So we can agree that any point and any line that I can imagine on a 
piece of material actually exists. Now, take a square sheet of paper that's 
exactly 1 square meter and cut a straight line diagonally from one point to 
another. What do you have now? Of course, you have a right triangle with 
two sides of 1 meter each. What's the size of the third side? I dont think 
I have to write the equation of the Pythagorean Theorem in order for you to 
agree that it's square root of 2. But square root of 2 has infinite decimal 
digits, how is it possible to have the side of my paper triangle have a 
length that has infinite decimal digits? It isn't, we can't achieve such 
accuracy in the real world. But what if I never actually cut the sheet of 
paper? The diagonal distance between it's points should still be square 
root of two. And let's say that having a square piece of paper that's 
exactly 1 square meter is impossible as well. The fact that I can't cut a 
material into that exact shape and size because of lack of ability to get 
that kind of accuracy doesn't mean that the lines that I SHOULD cut in 
order to get that shape aren't there. So, if you look at a surface, There 
many places on it, infinite to be exact, on which you can cut to get a 
square that's 1 square meter in size. And that means that the diagonal 
distance between it's points also exists, so the line with a length of 
square root of 2 does exist in the real world. It's not a matter of whether 
it exists or not, or if it is a "thing" as you said, but it's a matter of 
not being produceable.
comments.author: Simon Michalo

comments.text:
thanks but I do understand both very basic maths and the essence of the 
paradox..

It seems that you don't understand what I am trying to show.. that is that 
there is a fundamental difference between the conceptual (imaginary, you 
could even say fictitious) world of maths, which you don’t seem to fully 
grasp… and the actual physical world of things and forces .. which you seem 
not to grasp at all..

lets begin with the physical..
No.. half of one atom does not equal .5 of an atom..
This is simply not true in any way..

Firstly.. what do you mean by atom..?
In it’s broadest sense this could refer to an uncountable large number of 
things..
Which may behave in an uncountable large number of ways.. we just don’t 
know yet..

In it’s more specific sense it is a general term for at least 118 types of 
things that we have described in some detail.. all of which have unique 
properties and behaviours..

You might like to google Nuclear Fission at this point.. for example..
If you split uranium 236 in half you DO NOT get 2X .05 Uranium 236 atoms
You get 1x Krypton 92 atom + 1X Barium 141 atom + a huge fucking explosion 
of energy..
I’m sorry to have to inform you that the real world is unpredictable and 
does not follow your logic or math..

Another example at a different scale..
If I were to take a chainsaw and run it from the top of your head to your 
testicles (assuming you to be male) and then place the left half of what 
resulted in a bag would that be .5 of you..? Would to carry half of your 
memories and skills.. would it run half as fast but require only half the 
food..

If I invented a symbol for the contents of this bag say ‘ttp’ would I then 
be able to multiply this by 5..?
if I took a larger bag containing ttpX5/2 to your mother would she be 
delighted..? cos she would be able to throw away one ttp/2 and use the 
other four to make two sons..? how wonderful..?

No.. none of this would happen.. slice you in half we get a bag of blood 
and bones.. it has o% of your personality, knowledge and skills..

even at a more basic level.. cut a table and chair in half with the same 
chainsaw and you DO NOT get 2X .05 table and chairs.. You get a pile of 
wood.. which does not stand up and can’t be sat on or eaten off.. you can’t 
half sit on a half chair or half eat you dinner of a flat bit of wood with 
two legs on one side.. It’s just not how the world works..

Why do mathematicians remain under the illusion that if you can make a 
symbol up for something then it must actually exist.. you say thing like 
“Therefore there must be an infinite number of midpoints”.. this is called 
logical conjecture.. it’s very useful sometime.. but in the physical 
sciences it’s a beginning.. you than have to go and FIND these points and 
describe them.. to say they simply ‘must’ exist in not enough..

As for infinity.. In the real world there may or may not be infinitely 
large object,, by we can never know this by definition.. If we have any 
information about the limits of an object then it’s not infinite.. and if 
we don’t then we can’t say whether it’s infinite or not..  comprendé..?

Now back to maths..

again have you any evidence that your process can happen infinity..? has 
anybody ever done it infinitely..? clearly not.. so when you say it can 
happen infinitely what you mean is in a purely conceptual landscape you can 
see no reason why this process should have to end..

In the real world the process that you started required some pixels and 
some power.. so it’s infinite iteration would require and infinitely large 
computer with an infinitely large screen and a never ending power source.. 
this may sound pedantic but it’s important to understand..

when we say infinite in maths what it actually means in any useful sense is 
something like ‘and so on and so on’ .. and what’s interesting is often the 
most useful thinking about infinities is the convergent infinities which 
‘tend towards a limit’.. so we have limits again..

and again you cannot even know if a process can go on indefinitely for the 
same reasons as the infinitely large thing.. find a limit.. it’s not 
infinite.. don’t find any limits.. you can’t say whether they exist or not..

don’t get me wrong I love maths.. it goes from incredibly useful to mind 
blowingly beautiful.. but it’s when people start thinking that it’s real 
that they get stuck in the gaps between how they they imagine the world 
ought logically to behave and how it actually does behave.. and this is 
neither useful nor beautiful..
comments.author: paulflute

comments.text:
I don't think you understand. Half of 1 is .5
Half of .5 is .25
Half of .25  is  .125.
This can happen infinitely even with space at matter.
Half of 1 atom is .5 of an atom...etc etc.

This argument says that in order to travel from point A to point B there is 
a mid point that must be crossed. Between point A and midpoint of AB there 
is another midpoint.

My logical argument inspired by Zeno's paradox:
1) There is a midpoint between every two points.
2) A midpoint is a point.
3) Therefore there must be an infinite number of midpoints between any two 
points.
4) In order to travel from one point to another, you must cross through all 
the points in between.
5) It is impossible to travel through an infinite number of points by 
definition.
6) Therefore you cannot travel.

This obviously is not true but the fascinating thing about it is the 
logical argument seems to be sound.
comments.author: tatripp

comments.text:
+tatripp I disagree. Can you provide an example of something being divided 
infinitely..?  I'll answer that for you. No you can't.. because THNINGS 
can't be divided infinitely.. This is because things are made of stuff and 
stuff has limits.. 
Infinity is not a thing.. It's a concept.. It's a useful mathematical 
concept,, but it's no more.. it's not even really a process and is never 
actually done in maths..
Whenever the concept of infinity comes into play people have to try to 
figure out different ways to approximate it.. sometimes these 
approximations are rougher than other but always result in something that 
is approximate.. the problem is that when this is forgotten and the next 
generation begin to use the approximation as if it was the actual thing you 
get these semantic nonsenses that occur in the gap between the two.. this 
being one of the first.. a more recent example being the -1/12 as the sum 
of all integers and then being used in string theory as if it really was 
the answer.. rather than an product of the approximation.. It's important 
to understand the difference between words concepts processes and actual 
real physical things that exist and how these all relate and where the 
boundaries are..both of practical usefulness and of intellectual 
exploration..

+p.sharath kumar Theoretically, within the constraint of human capability, 
he can't reach his destination. But, mathematically it is 100% possible. 
It's not really a paradox because it does have a solution now.

And even if he walks the full distance, he has already traversed all the 
halves and reaches his destination. But if you keep going half the distance 
you'll still reach your destination as explained by infinite geometric 
series.


The reason people see it as a paradox is because they picture Zeno walking, 
stopping, walking stopping etc. Obviously infinity seems a bit extreme if 
you move 3 mph and stop for several seconds.


But I don't see this as a paradox because I would eventually reach my 
destination.

comments.text:
+Nickuncle​
Hmm... I am still in high school..
It definitely converges... 
The method you used has puzzled me since ever... It is based on the 
definition of 'infinite infinity' reason why you were able to replace the 
GP in the second step with an 'x'
Thinking otherwise.. 
The GP in step 1 must have ∞ terms... But the one in the second contains 
(∞-1) terms..
Now obviously that -1 doesn't really matter to infinity but it would have 
some effect to the sum... However small?? 

I have always learnt that this is a limiting sum and is never exactly equal 
to one.. 

Okay lemme ask you one thing... What is the value of:

[1/2+1/4+1/8+1/16..... ∞]
Where [ . ] denotes the greatest integer function.. 

Is it 1 or 0?
comments.author: Amogh Sharma

comments.text:
+Amogh Sharma Your math doesn't make sense. Infinitely there will be a 
perfect sum. There's a comment that explained it in simple comprehensible 
terms:

"let x = 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8.....

Multiply the equation by 2

2x = 1 + 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 .....

2x = 1 + (1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8....)

2x = 1 + x  [ because x = (1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8....) ]

2x - x = 1

x = 1 "



Really it's just an infinite geometric series. It was the definition of 
confusion when I first learned it back in High School, but it's now 
generally accepted that it converges.
comments.author: Nickuncle

top_comment.text:
Lol, he didn't solve anything...this is still undefined by mathematicians 
today!! Think About it, if you add up any sum an infinite amount of 
times(even if it's .000000000000000000001) it's infinity. Anything times 
infinity is...infinity. This has to do with the fact that time and reality 
is in a different dimension. In math undefined can be 0, and some 
mathematicians have looked at infinity as 0. If you assume the universe is 
infinite then all math is undefined...which would in theory explain why 
this Damn problem is so mind boggling...﻿

is impossible", then he goes on to explain... The reason we see it like

positive or negative, times infinity is infinity... Either way on the

comments.author: Phraser

top_comment.text:
Zeno was simply a curious old man with absolutely no knowledge of 
infinitesimals or geometric sequences, since calculus was only invented 
some 2 millennia later. Even so, surely he would have observed the ability 
of humans to walk from point A to B without any difficulty? Where actual 
mechanics is inconsistent with a paradox presented by a thought experiment, 
is it really still a paradox? ﻿
top_comment.author: yifuj

comments.text:

movement was just a sensual illusion, read on the Ealactics if you want to 
know more

top_comment.text:
Reminds me of the saying, "To every rule there is an exception". That can't 
be true, because then there would have to be an exception to that rule, 
IOW, a rule t which there is no exception.﻿
top_comment.author: Rose NoHo

comments.text: then it`s not true.
comments.author: Jojo Meins

comments.text:
And what if the rule "to every rule there's an exeption" applies to all 
rules exept itself?
comments.author: Rockyblack smith

comments.text:
If this statement was true, there had to be a rule that says that there is 
an exception for every rule. Otherwise the statement was false.
But there cannot be a rule that says that there is an exception to any 
rule, because this would lead to a paradox. So the statement is not true.

captions.text: This is Zeno of Elea,
an ancient Greek philosopher
famous for inventing a number of paradoxes,
arguments that seem logical,
but whose conclusion is absurd or contradictory.
For more than 2,000 years,
Zeno's mind-bending riddles have inspired
mathematicians and philosophers
to better understand the nature of infinity.
One of the best known of Zeno's problems
is called the dichotomy paradox,
which means, "the paradox of cutting in two" in ancient Greek.
It goes something like this:
After a long day of sitting around, thinking,
Zeno decides to walk from his house to the park.
The fresh air clears his mind
and help him think better.
In order to get to the park,
he first has to get half way to the park.
This portion of his journey
takes some finite amount of time.
Once he gets to the halfway point,
he needs to walk half the remaining distance.
Again, this takes a finite amount of time.
Once he gets there, he still needs to walk
half the distance that's left,
which takes another finite amount of time.
This happens again and again and again.
You can see that we can keep going like this forever,
dividing whatever distance is left
into smaller and smaller pieces,
each of which takes some finite time to traverse.
So, how long does it take Zeno to get to the park?
Well, to find out, you need to add the times
of each of the pieces of the journey.
The problem is, there are infinitely many of these finite-sized pieces.
So, shouldn't the total time be infinity?
This argument, by the way, is completely general.
It says that traveling from any location to any other location
should take an infinite amount of time.
In other words, it says that all motion is impossible.
This conclusion is clearly absurd,
but where is the flaw in the logic?
To resolve the paradox,
it helps to turn the story into a math problem.
Let's supposed that Zeno's house is one mile from the park
and that Zeno walks at one mile per hour.
Common sense tells us that the time for the journey
should be one hour.
But, let's look at things from Zeno's point of view
and divide up the journey into pieces.
The first half of the journey takes half an hour,
the next part takes quarter of an hour,
the third part takes an eighth of an hour,
and so on.
Summing up all these times,
we get a series that looks like this.
"Now", Zeno might say,
"since there are infinitely many of terms
on the right side of the equation,
and each individual term is finite,
the sum should equal infinity, right?"
This is the problem with Zeno's argument.
As mathematicians have since realized,
it is possible to add up infinitely many finite-sized terms
and still get a finite answer.
"How?" you ask.
Well, let's think of it this way.
Let's start with a square that has area of one meter.
Now let's chop the square in half,
and then chop the remaining half in half,
and so on.
While we're doing this,
let's keep track of the areas of the pieces.
The first slice makes two parts,
each with an area of one-half
The next slice divides one of those halves in half,
and so on.
But, no matter how many times we slice up the boxes,
the total area is still the sum of the areas of all the pieces.
Now you can see why we choose this particular way
of cutting up the square.
We've obtained the same infinite series
as we had for the time of Zeno's journey.
As we construct more and more blue pieces,
to use the math jargon,
as we take the limit as n tends to infinity,
the entire square becomes covered with blue.
But the area of the square is just one unit,
and so the infinite sum must equal one.
Going back to Zeno's journey,
we can now see how how the paradox is resolved.
Not only does the infinite series sum to a finite answer,
but that finite answer is the same one
that common sense tells us is true.
Zeno's journey takes one hour.

title: What is Zeno's Dichotomy Paradox? - Colm Kelleher
